quoteLast: ; noon; the afternoon or evening.  Hamilton (1980) suggests that "noon" makes good contextual sense, since the witch's son finds Florimell as dazzling as "the bright Sunne"}
title: The Faerie Queene — Volume 01

quoteTime: about nine o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: , the Norman army marching from Hastings by the spot where Crowhurst Park is now seen, to Telham Hill, the “Hetheland” of the chroniclers. Here the Norman knights put on their armour, and here William made his vow that if victory were given him he would build a great abbey on the spot where he saw the emblazoned English banner of the Fighting Man flung proudly upon the morning breeze.
title: The Hastings Road and the "Happy Springs of Tunbridge"
author: Harper, Charles G. (Charles George), 1863-1943

quoteTime: about nine o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: , the Commissioner proceeded to hear and decide the case in the Circuit Court room, in which were stationed about sixty men serving as the Marshal's guard. Seth J.
title:

quoteFirst: Stanton frequently worked late at night, keeping his carriage waiting for him. I never worked at night, as my eyes would not allow it. I got to my office
quoteTime: about nine o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: , and I stayed there nearly the whole day, for I made it a rule never to go away until my desk was cleared. When I arrived I usually found on my table a big pile of papers which were to be acted on, papers of every sort that had come to me from the different departments of the office.
title:
Recollections of the Civil War
With the Leaders at Washington and in the Field in the Sixties
author: Dana, Charles A. (Charles Anderson), 1819-1897

quoteFirst: "_Saturday, September 16_. Clear and cold in the early morning. Started
quoteLast: Lined our boats past a difficult rapid. Too many rocks, not enough water. Two or three miles below this I had some difficulty in a rapid, as the pin of a rowlock lifted out of the socket when in the middle of rough water.
title: Through the Grand Canyon from Wyoming to Mexico
author: Kolb, E. L. (Ellsworth Leonardson), 1876-; Wister, Owen, 1860-1938 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteTime: About nine o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: , on the 28th December, we left Macon and rode thirty-one miles distance to the Indian agency, on the left bank of Flint river, called by the Indians, Thlo-no-teas-kah. The road was partly sandy, partly rocky, but extremely uneven.
title: Travels Through North America, During the Years 1825 and 1826. v. 1-2
author: Bernhard, Duke of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach, 1792-1862

quoteLast: they began carrying the fuel--wood and kerosene--that was to be used for the cremation, and at about 12 a.m. one Londoño, by order of the criminal Macedo, set fire to the unfortunate victims of the Ocainas tribe. This smouldering pile of human flesh remained there until about 10 a.m. on the next day.
title:
The Putumayo, the Devil's Paradise
Travels in the Peruvian Amazon Region and an Account of the Atrocities Committed upon the Indians Therein

quoteTime: About nine o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: the curtains were drawn by the Asafeta, followed by a single valet carrying a basin full of caudle.  Hyghens, during my convalescence, explained to me how this caudle was made, and in fact concocted some for me to taste.

quoteFirst: For the whole of that night did we continue beating up along the edge of the ice, in the teeth of a whole gale of wind; at last,
quoteTime: about nine o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: ,--but two short hours before the moment at which it had been agreed we should bear up, and abandon the attempt,--we came up with a long low point of ice, that had stretched further to the Westward than any we had yet doubled; and there, beyond, lay an open sea!--open not only to the Northward and Westward, but also to the Eastward! You can imagine my excitement." Turn the hands up, Mr.
title:
Letters from High Latitudes
Being Some Account of a Voyage in 1856 of the Schooner Yacht "Foam" to Iceland, Jan Meyen, and Spitzbergen
author: Dufferin and Ava, Frederick Temple Blackwood, Marquis of, 1826-1902

quoteFirst: Under a standing rule, the twelve hundred prisoners were counted twice each day, the first count being made
quoteLast: , and the last about four in the afternoon. This duty was habitually done by the clerk of the prison, E.W. Ross, a civilian employed by the commandant.
title: Famous Adventures and Prison Escapes of the Civil War
author: Cable, George Washington, 1844-1925 [Editor]; Duke, Basil Wilson, 1838-1916; Hines, Thomas Henry, 1838-1898; Moran, Frank E., -1892; Pittenger, William, 1840-1904; Richards, A. E. quoteFirst: Hour after hour passed, and he began to think that if he were only free he would not mind about anything else, though if he lost all his bets, and lost his horses, he would be without a penny in the world--in fact, he would be hardly able to pay his losses.  Then he remembered that it was the day the mail-cart passed along that road, and he calculated the time at which it would pass.  It was
quoteTime: about nine o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: when he had been tied, and at about sunset the cart would pass, judging by the time at which it generally left Buffels Drift.  He could not see the road from where he was, and the sand would prevent him hearing the cart as it came along; but as the sun went down and the time for the cart came near, he kept up a shouting, his voice growing hoarser and weaker, as he was afraid, every minute.
title: Luck at the Diamond Fields
author: Belgrave, Dalrymple J., 1851-1922

quoteLast: , when I grasped the fact that the artillery was getting into position.  It was difficult for me to make out these arrangements, situated as I was a full mile from the advancing troops, though in an advantageous position for witnessing the attack from the top side of the north gate, built like a railway arch in the surrounding wall of the town, a wall twenty feet high, and surrounded by the edifice already mentioned--a kind of pagoda erection.
title: In the Yellow Sea
author: Frith, Henry, 1840-

quoteFirst: Demolition charges were laid and fired
quoteLast: on August 9th. The crew returned to Krupp's.

quoteFirst: Even as I set out from Hampstead,
quoteLast: , I had been able to guess that some of my fuses had somehow anticipated the appointed hour: for I saw three red hazes at various points in the air, and heard the far vague booming of an occasional explosion; and by 11 A.M. I felt sure that a large region of north-eastern London must be in flames.
title: The Purple Cloud
author: Shiel, M. P. (Matthew Phipps), 1865-1947

quoteLast: , crushing a newspaper in his hand; what he had read there had rendered him livid with helpless anger.  He found Jimmy Wren awaiting him.

quoteLast: we were relieved and called in. As we were being relieved by the Twelfth Maine we had to pass over a place commanded by the sharpshooters of the enemy. The bullets whizzed most unpleasantly near, killing one man of the Thirteenth Connecticut.

quoteLast: , we set off—Joan on the strawberry, balanced easily on an old sack, which was all her saddle; and I on Molly, that now was sound again and chafing to be so idle. As we set out, Joan’s father for the first time took some notice of me, standing at the door to see us off and shouting after us to bring home some account of the wrestling.
title:
The Splendid Spur
Being Memoirs of the Adventures of Mr. John Marvel, a Servant of His Late Majesty King Charles I, in the Years 1642-3
